Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 45119-001 
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA)  
February 2012 
 
 
 
Promoting Innovations in Wastewater Management in 
Asia and the Pacific  
 (Financed by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction)  
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
DMC  –  developing member country 
MDG  –  Millennium Development Goal 
PPP  –  public–private partnership 
TA  –  technical assistance 
WFP  –  Water Financing Program 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—Capacity development technical assistance (R-CDTA)  
Targeting classification  –  General intervention  
Sector (subsector)  –  Water supply and other municipal infrastructure and services (water 
supply and sanitation) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Environmental  sustainability  (eco-efficiency);  private  sector 
development  (public–private  partnerships);  capacity  development 
(client relations, network, and partnership development)  
Climate change  –  Climate change mitigation  
Location impact  –  Urban (high), rural (medium), national (medium), regional (medium)

Vice-President  B. N. Lohani, Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development  
Director General  X. Yao, Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD) 
Director  G. Kim, Sustainable Infrastructure Division, RSDD  
    
Team leader  A. Chiplunkar, Lead Water Supply and Sanitation Specialist (Public-Private

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Strategy  2020  supports  water  as  a  crosscutting  core  business  area  of  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) operations for infrastructure and the environment.1 Consistent with 
the  emphasis  on  results-based  management  and  accountability,  ADB’s  Water  Financing 
Program (WFP) sets an example by announcing these specific targeted outcomes by 2020: (i) 
500 million people with access to safe drinking water supply and improved sanitation,2 (ii) 170 
million people with reduced risk of flooding, (iii) 95 million people with more productive and 
efficient irrigation and drainage services, (iv) integrated water resource management introduced 
in 30 river basins, and (v) improved water governance through national water reforms and 
capacity development.3 At the Water Leaders Summit of the inaugural Singapore International 
Water Week in June 2008, ADB outlined a seven-point agenda for countries in the region to 
prioritize water investment, including increasing investments in water supply and sanitation in 
urban and rural areas, and adopting a comprehensive sanitation approach “from toilet to river” 
to  address  household  and  environmental  sanitation  (comprising  septage,  wastewater,  and 
sludge management and reuse).  
2.  ADB has committed to increasing the coverage of sanitation, hygiene, and wastewater 
management in the region through its Water Operational Plan, 2011–2020,4 supported by the 
WFP. The plan’s priority for wastewater management is (i) expanded wastewater management 
and reuse, (ii) expanded knowledge and capacity development using technology and innovation 
more directly, and (iii) enhanced partnerships with the private sector.  
3.  This  regional  capacity  development  technical  assistance  (TA) 5  will  support  the 
development and increased investments in wastewater management projects in accordance 
with  the  Water  Operational  Plan.  Countries  in  the  region  were  consulted  on  the  TA6 and 
generally agreed that, if health and economic benefits are to be realized, septage, wastewater, 
and sludge management systems must be an integrated component of improved sanitation and 
not an optional extra. The design and monitoring framework is attached as Appendix 1.  
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Governments and donors often neglect sanitation in their development priorities. Many 
countries will not likely reach the United Nations’ Millennium Development Goal (MDG) for 
sanitation coverage; disparities between rich and poor and between urban and rural areas are 
significant.  About  1.8  billion  people  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific  have  no  access  to  improved 
                                                 
1 ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
2 Improved sanitation is defined as facilities that ensure hygienic separation of excreta from human contact, such as 
connection to a public sewer, connection to a septic system, pour-flush latrines, simple pit latrines, and ventilated 
improved pit latrines. Sanitation solutions that are not considered "improved" include public or shared latrines, open 
pit latrines, and bucket latrines. (World Health Organization and United Nations Children’s Fund Joint Monitoring 
Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation. 2004. Meeting the MDG Drinking Water and Sanitation Target: A 
Mid-Term Assessment of Progress. Geneva.) 
3  ADB. 2011. Revised design monitoring framework for Water Financing Program. Manila. 
4  ADB. 2011. Water Operational Plan 2011-2020. Manila. 
5 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 7 December 2011. 
6 The following countries have confirmed support for this TA: Bangladesh, Bhutan, Georgia, India, Indonesia, Lao 
People’s  Democratic  Republic,  Malaysia,  Marshall  Islands,  Mongolia,  Nepal,  Papua  New  Guinea,  Pakistan, 
Philippines, Sri Lanka, Solomon Islands, Thailand, Tonga, Uzbekistan, and Viet Nam.

2 
 
sanitation.7 More work is needed to ensure that investments in sanitation are increased to reach 
the MDG sanitation target and the targets set in the WFP. 
5.  Given limited freshwater resources and the huge demand for water, water pollution is a 
major problem in Asia and the Pacific. While efforts to meet the MDG target on sanitation are 
increasing, they focus more on increasing coverage, particularly access to toilets. However, 
quality and sustainability of sanitation facilities and adequate treatment of wastewater and 
sludge remain an issue. Up to 90% of wastewater generated is untreated or inadequately 
treated  and  dumped  in  lakes,  coastal  waters,  rivers,  and  water  courses  that  are  already 
stressed  and  polluted—affecting  water  supplies,  human  health,  fisheries,  livelihoods, 
ecosystems, and economic development.8  
6.  Attracting  additional  funds  into  the  sector  and  delivering  environmental  sanitation 
services at scale remain a challenge. Currently, financing falls far short due to the unclear return 
of investments, the inability to scale up interventions, and lack of access to existing financing 
mechanisms.  In  particular,  wastewater  management  is  seen  as  a  very  poor  investment. 
Typically, up-front capital costs are huge, and inadequate budget is allocated for operation and 
maintenance costs. When combined with inadequate capacity, lack of household demand, and 
low willingness to pay, wastewater management becomes a low priority in government agendas. 
The  private  sector  is  not  willing  to  invest  because  demand  is  not  clear,  and  policy  and 
institutional constraints make investments risky. Without support to make septage, wastewater, 
and sludge management projects bankable and sustainable, the business potential is not being 
captured. The development and implementation of viable and sustainable septage, wastewater, 
and sludge management projects require (i) enabling conditions provided by governments,  
(ii) a paradigm shift in doing business in environmental sanitation, and (iii) adoption of cost-
effective technologies. 
7.  Initiatives in wastewater and sludge reuse are urgently need to help relieve pressures 
caused in water scarce areas, and address related food and energy security issues. Harvesting 
nutrients (for fertilizers), methane and biogas (for energy and carbon credits), and water (for 
irrigation,  power  cooling,  industrial  and  other  non-potable  uses)  offers  income-generating 
opportunities. Emerging trends in wastewater and sludge reuse show huge market potential that 
can  change  the  economics  of  sanitation.  This  will  help  in  understanding  that  water  and 
wastewater have an economic value—an appreciation currently missing in many parts of Asia 
and the Pacific. 
8.  The TA intends to move advocacy into potential business opportunities by conducting 
roundtables among stakeholders (primarily public sector agencies and private investors) in 
selected countries.9 Proven solutions that can be potentially applied to a local situation will be 
discussed at the roundtable as a sustainable business opportunity for septage, wastewater, and 
sludge  management.  ADB  and  other  development  partners  may  then  potentially  consider 
developing these opportunities as investment opportunities with private sector participation.

III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
9.  Moving  forward  with  innovation  and  a  change  in  the  way  wastewater  management 
services are delivered in Asia and the Pacific will require key drivers of change: knowledge, 
technology, financing and incentives, and awareness and advocacy. The TA goes beyond 
knowledge management, and advocacy and awareness campaigns, as it links to a deliverable 
that is a sustainable investment opportunity to attract the private sector. To drive an innovative 
approach, it will be necessary to engage with: 
(i)  development partners, research institutions, technology, and service providers  to 
share  and  assess  existing,  innovative,  and  emerging  technologies;  solution 
options; and case studies;  
(ii)  DMCs in country and regional contexts to raise awareness, analyze the pros and 
cons of the existing systems and identify real needs, recognize what technology 
and  financing  options  are  available  for  practical  and  doable  solutions,  and 
enhance DMC capacity to plan and execute actions that would result in increased 
sanitation and wastewater treatment coverage and promote the reuse of treated 
wastewater in their country; and  
(iii)  the private sector to increase its role in applying cost-effective technologies and 
financing wastewater management infrastructure.  
A.   Impact and Outcome 
10.  The TA impact will be enhanced sustainable investments in environmental sanitation 
projects.  The  TA  outcome  will  be  increased  awareness  and  enhanced  institutional  and 
professional capacity of DMCs in developing viable and sustainable septage, wastewater, and 
sludge management and reuse plans and/or projects. 
B.   Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will promote and support innovative approaches to the delivery of wastewater 
management  services  through  knowledge  management,  packaging  of  technology  options, 
incentives  and  financing  mechanisms,  and  conduct  of  knowledge  exchange  and  capacity 
development  activities  to  change  mindsets,  and  expand  the  range  and  scale  of  septage, 
wastewater, and sludge management in Asia and the Pacific.  
12.  Knowledge. The knowledge drive will involve building up knowledge on environmental 
sanitation solutions. The TA will provide support for the development of (i) a structured database 
of working models and case studies outlining the sanitation need, technical solution options, 
institutional settings, and financial viability aspects and application areas; and (ii) a virtual 
knowledge center, a free access web-based information system and network, for easy access to 
the case studies, models, information briefs, technology and financing options, and investment 
and business opportunities. 
13.  Technology. The technology drive will involve more intense use of specific technology 
datasheets and their applications for different treated output standards required for various end-
uses,  and  will  focus  on  appropriateness  and  cost-effectiveness.  A  variety  of  options  are 
available (conventional, innovative, emerging, under development, under research for future 
potential) for collection, conveyance, treatment, and disposal of waste and for reuse of treated 
waste for different uses. Wastewater and sludge can be harvested for energy and/or nutrients,

or  recycle  applications,  and  (ii)  technology  datasheets  or  information  briefs  on  technology 
applications for different levels of treatment and standards required for various end-uses.  
14.  Financing and incentives. The financing and incentives drive will involve development 
of business opportunity briefs, affordable and innovative financing mechanisms, and methods 
for extracting resources (e.g., water, energy, nutrients) from wastewater to fast-track wastewater 
investment projects. If wastewater is seen as a resource with potential revenues, then the 
incentive package changes. The TA will provide support for (i) development of business and 
investment opportunity briefs based on prefeasibility studies demonstrating financial viability of 
sanitation solution options and dissemination for use by utilities, agencies, and other service 
providers and investors; and (ii) preparation of a paper on delivery and financing mechanism 
options (including public–private partnerships), and design of project financing with incentives 
(e.g.,  wastewater  revolving  fund,  wastewater  bonds,  output-based  aid,  Clean  Development 
Mechanism and carbon credits, guarantee mechanism, affordable lending terms, and other 
financing modalities).  
15.  Awareness  and  advocacy.  The  awareness  and  advocacy  drive  will  comprise 
aggressive development and dissemination of knowledge and advocacy products on technology 
and financing options, health and environmental impacts, energy costs and/or savings, and 
benefits of various models of wastewater management to policy-makers, planners, investors, 
and beneficiary communities, including women. It will influence the acceptance of a mosaic of 
options or a range of investment opportunities, among decision-makers. This component would 
be  the  key  networking  and  knowledge  exchange  platform  through  roundtables  bringing  all 
stakeholders (e.g., public sector, private investors, technology providers, research organizations, 
users) to discuss and move forward on identified business opportunities. The TA will provide 
support for (i) subregional and in-country conferences; investment roundtables; and capacity 
development workshops to trigger the use of technology and financing options, and move 
forward  on  the  identified  business  and  investment  opportunities;  (ii)  advocacy  product 
development  and  dissemination,  e.g.,  policy  briefs,  multimedia,  articles,  brochures,  among 
others; and (iii) knowledge product development and dissemination, e.g., toolkits on a range of 
technology options and financing arrangements, and other training and instructive materials. 
C.    Cost and Financing  
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,000,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and administered by ADB. The detailed cost 
estimates and financing plan are shown in Appendix 2.  
D.   Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. The Sustainable Infrastructure Division of 
the Regional and Sustainable Development Department will be the focal point for this TA. It will 
be responsible for coordinating TA activities in collaboration with regional departments and with 
support from dedicated consultants in the areas of knowledge management, sector data and 
research,  financing  and  partnership  arrangements,  and  fund  and  administrative  support. 
Activities  under  the  knowledge  and  technology  drives  will  be  region-wide.  Case  studies, 
technology and financing options and applications, and other related information would come 
from various DMCs as well as other regions and sectors. Activities under the financing and 
incentives  drive  and  awareness  and  advocacy  drive,  such  as  subregional  and  in-country 
dialogue,  investor  roundtables,  prefeasibility  studies,  business  opportunity  briefs,  capacity 
development workshops, and pre-project preparatory work will be conducted in the eight priority 
countries.10 The roundtables to discuss investment and business opportunity briefs will be taken 
                                                 
10 Bangladesh, India, Indonesia, Mongolia, Philippines, Sri Lanka, Uzbekistan, and Viet Nam.

5 
up only where the government and stakeholders show interest, and utilities show commitment in 
developing the projects for investment. Actual development into projects and/or investments and 
project implementation are outside the scope of the TA.  
18.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  from  March  2012  to  February  2016.  The  Sustainable 
Infrastructure Division will prepare required progress reports, supervise TA activities, and make 
reports available through the ADB water website. The Water Community of Practice will monitor 
TA progress. The TA progress and outputs will be disseminated through websites of ADB and 
the Japan Sanitation Consortium, which is the regional sanitation knowledge hub of the Asia-
Pacific  Water  Forum.  Knowledge  sharing  will  be  through  the  dissemination  of  knowledge 
products, and through seminars of the Water Community of Practice, and other events, forums, 
and workshops. 
19.  The  development  partners  are  expected  to  support  TA  implementation.  Support 
identified  for  each  partner  in  the  Omega  Action  Alliance  includes  the  (i)  United  Nations 
Secretary-General's Advisory Board, as the networking partner, will assist in advocacy and 
finding financial support; and (ii) International Water Association and Center for Science and 
Environment will provide case studies and technical and knowledge support. During the Second 
ADB–DMC and Partners Sanitation Dialogue in May 2011, development partners, and private 
sector and civil society representatives committed to contribute to the implementation of each of 
the drivers. A change of the TA scope may be required to include any additional financing made 
available by other partners or agencies.  
20.  Approximately  23  person-months  of  two  international  consultants  and  142  person-
months of five national consultants will be needed for TA implementation. The major areas of 
expertise are expected to include the technical, economic, financial, policy, institutional, social, 
environmental,  information  technology  and  multimedia  disciplines  related  to  septage, 
wastewater,  and  sludge  management  investments,  technology  and  financing  options, 
knowledge  management,  advocacy,  and  capacity  development.  The  consultants  will  be 
recruited as individual consultants, with significant inputs from national consultants, under the 
oversight of an international specialist. Consultants will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The outline terms 
of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. Resource persons will be recruited for the 10 
subregional  and  country  workshops  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants. The TA does not envisage contracting the partner institutions directly. Partners are 
expected to identify 10 case studies and contribute information in a specified template. Site 
visits may be necessary to prepare the information as a knowledge product.  
21.  Appendix 4 shows the framework for the four key drivers of change for the promotion of 
innovative approaches in the delivery of wastewater management services, and the framework 
of the roles and responsibilities of each institution and organization.  
22.  ADB will procure equipment and materials financed by the TA in accordance with its 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA 
will be done in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time).
